PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: EQT and AGL reportedly withdrew from their bids for Vocus due to concerns regarding the retail unit
content:
AUSTRALIA

Bluescope Steel (BSL AT) - Co. lowered its FY19 underlying EBITDA guidance to AUD 1.35bln from AUD 1.40bln and will extend share buyback by up to AUD 250mln. (Newswires)

Coles (COL AT) - Co. CEO said they will adjust unsustainable strategies, while it targets AUD 1.0bln in cumulative cost savings by FY23. (Newswires)

Incitec Pivot (IPL AT) - Co. Chairman retires due to health reasons and will be replaced by current director Kruger. (Newswires)

MacMahon (MAH AT) - Co. will acquire GDF Group in which it sees the deal to generate revenue of AUD 180mln and EBITDA of around AUD 20mln for FY20. (Newswires)

Northern Star Resources (NST AT) - Australian operations continue to produce strong EBITDA margins of more than 45%. (Newswires)

Resolute Mining (RSG AT) - Co. received approval for a London IPO with trading expected to begin on June 20th. (Newswires)

Stockland (SGP AT) - Co. denies speculation it is planning to replace CEO Steinert. (Newswires)

Vocus Group (VOC AT) - EQT and AGL reportedly withdrew from their bids for Vocus due to concerns regarding the retail unit. (Newswires)

Webjet (WEB AT) - Co. affirms FY19 EBITDA at AUD 120mln, while it presented a blockchain backed reservation and payment system. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT) - Co. long time employees claim that they are being forced to apply for the same job for lower pay under the new operating structure. (AFR)

Other News - Australia Treasurer Frydenberg said the government is to introduce an income tax package worth around AUD 158bln during first week of Parliament. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Komatsu (6301 JT) - Komatsu Mining acquires Timberock International which is a manufacturer of underground hard rock drill components. (Newswires)

Sekisui Chemical (4204 JT) - Co. will acquire US-based aerospace component producer AIM Aerospace in a deal valued at USD 510mln. (Nikkei)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co.’s Vision Fund is spearheading a USD 205mln funding round for San Francisco-based Collective Health. (Nikkei)

Tokai Carbon (5301 JT) - Co. will acquire Germany’s COBEX in a deal valued at JPY 100bln. (Newswires)

Toshiba (6502 JT) - Co. and Aecom (ACM) signs agreement to partner on nuclear decommissioning services in Japan. (Newswires)

Yamato (9064 JT) - Co. plans on resuming moving services in September. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. reportedly may win a manufacturing order from Intel (INTC). (Newswires)

Refiners - South Korea's major refiners are likely to see weak earnings for Q2 amid low refining margins, according to analysts. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China’s economic regulators refuse to rule out rare earths card against US. (SCMP)

China's Global Times Editor suggested that there is a lot of criticism in China's state media against the US at the moment which serves to mobilise Chinese society for a protracted trade war, while he added that the mutual hostility of public opinion makes a compromise more difficult. (Twitter)

China April UST holdings at USD 1.113trln (prev. USD 1.121trln in March); 2yr low. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Germany's Economy Minister Altmaier said the EU and US must urgently start negotiations on a trade deal which would also abolish all industrial goods tariffs, while he added that German companies need a level playing field in China and that he will raise the issue in talks in Beijing this week. (Newswires)

Bundesbank Monthly Report said the German economy is to contract slightly and the economic outlook will also decline mildly in Q2 as one-off effects that supported the expansion in Q1 fades. (Newswires)

EU may halt the customs union talks with Turkey according to a draft communique. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih expects global oil demand to exceed 100mln BPD in 2019 and commented that oil demand growth is holding up despite trade disputes. Al Falih also stated that Saudi oil production and exports during June and July are likely to be the same as the last few months, while he suggested OPEC are moving towards a consensus on extension of the output deal. (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh cannot attend OPEC on July 3rd-4th but has no problem for July 10th-12th. (Twitter)

Iran and Russia have signed a MOU related to oil & nuclear energy. (Shana)

EIA said US total shale regions oil production for July is seen up 70k BPD at 8.521mln BPD (vs. 85,000 BPD rise in June). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran said it would welcome a new approach from the Saudis aimed at decreasing tensions in the Middle East but added that Saudis lack understanding of regional variables via a militaristic and crisis-based approach, while there were separate comments from Iran's ambassador to the UK that suggested Iran is unfortunately heading towards a confrontation. (Newswires)

A senior Iranian lawmaker said Tehran is to exit the non-proliferation treaty if the EU fails to save the nuclear deal, while senior officials also stated that Iran is in charge of Gulf security and called on US forces to leave. (Newswires/Fars)

There was a suspected explosion close to the China-North Korea border which caused small earthquakes, although China later stated that the explosion near the China-North Korea border happened on their side and was not a nuclear test. (Newswires/AFP)

 

US

US NY Fed Manufacturing (Jun) -8.6 vs. Exp. 10.0 (Prev. 17.8). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) moved higher as the Paris air show kicked off and the aircraft maker secured a number of orders. Facebook (FB) moved higher after SunTrust was optimistic that the social media platforms new cryptocurrency could "dramatically" expand the co.’s total addressable market and growth prospects. Disney (DIS) was moved lower after being downgraded by Imperial. Apple (AAPL) edged higher as Credit Suisse noted “less bad” than expected China shipment data, although gains were capped as JPM cut their PT for the iPhone maker. Dish (DISH) was buoyant on reports that it was leading the race to buy divestures from the T-Mobile US/Sprint merger. On which note, Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) both opened higher, after reports late last Friday suggest the DoJ were close to approving the merger. Incyte (INCY) moved higher after the drugmaker’s Ruxolitinib cream met primary end points in a phase 2 study. Mosaic (MOS) caught a bid after being upgraded at BAML. Symantec (SYMC) was buoyant after the co. received an upgrade at Mizuho. Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) jumped higher at the open after being upgraded by BMO Capital. Deere (DE) moved higher after the co. was upgraded at Baird. Kinder Morgan (KMI) were under pressure after being downgraded at Stifel. LyondellBasell (LYB) opened lower after being downgraded at Deutsche Bank. Conversely Corteva (CTVA) was upgraded at Deutsche Bank, and duly caught a tail wind. Array BioPharma (ARRY) shot higher on the news that Pfizer (PFE) would purchase the firm at a large premium. The latter fell slightly. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher after CEO Musk deleted his Twitter account, only months after reaching a settlement with the SEC regarding his Twitter use. General Electric (GE) was under pressure on dual negative stories; 1) they announced plans to cut roughly 450 jobs at two Swiss sites as it looks to address "challenges on the global energy markets” and 2) GE Aviation found unexpected wear in a part of its new engine for Boeing’s new 777X passenger plane, resulting in several months of delays while the component is redesigned and tested. A flattening treasury curve did little to help financial names, such as Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C), who moved lower throughout the session. S&P 500 0.1% at 2890, NASDAQ-100 0.6% at 7527, Dow Jones 0.1% at 26113.

Monday’s uneventful session was evident in the Tplex too, which saw US 10 years move sideways. Early on USTs moved in sympathy with the Bund, which saw fresh record low yields, before catching some mild bidding on the back of the disappointing US NY Fed manufacturing data. At settlement yields were mainly unchanged aside from the front-end, where the 2-year yield rose by c. 1.5bps, which saw the 2s/10s flatten by c. 2bps. US T-note futures (M9) settled 1 tick higher at 126-31.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 17th June 2019: Markets move sideways ahead of key risk events
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries flat/up, Dollar flat, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Terrible US NY Fed Manufacturing Data; ECB’s de Guindos says if inflation expectations de-anchor, ECB will act; US/Iran tensions remain elevated as Iran/Russia ties strengthen
  • COMING UP: RBA Minutes, GE ZEW Data, EZ Final CPI; US, Building Permits, Housing Starts, API; NZ Current Account (Q1), ECB’s Draghi, de Guindos, Lane

 

* US NY FED MANUFACTURING: June’s NY Fed Manufacturing index fell to -8.6 from 17.8, well below Street expectations for 11.0, in what was also the lowest reading since October 2016. New orders index also posted a significant decline, falling 22 points to -12.0, whilst the index for number of employees fell 8 points to -3.5, its first negative value in over two years, pointing to a small decline in employment levels. The shipments index fell 7 points to 9.7, pointing to a modest increase in shipments and prices received index fell 6 points to 6.8, marking a fourth consecutive decline and pointing to an ongoing deceleration in selling price increase. Pantheon's Chief Economist notes "The terrible-looking Empire State survey was conducted in the middle of Trump's Mexico tariff threat. Usually the survey tracks China's Caixin PMI, so it likely will rebound strongly next month now that the Mexico fiasco is over."

* TRADE: China’s economic regulators refuse to rule out the rare earths card against US, reported SCMP during early trade. Later, China's Global Times Editor commented that there is a of criticism in China's state media against the US at the moment, which serves to mobilise Chinese society for a protracted trade war and that mutual hostility of public opinion makes a compromise more difficult. On the US/EU front: Germany's Economy Minister Altmaier said the EU and US must urgently start negotiations on a trade deal which would also abolish all industrial goods tariffs, before adding that German companies need a level playing field in China, an issue which he will raise in talks in Beijing this week. On the US/Canada/Mexico front, a US Chamber of Commerce official said an objective to get a vote on the USMCA before the August congressional recess is a reasonable goal. Away from the US, the EU may halt the customs union talks with Turkey, according to a draft communique.

* IRAN: Iran and Russia on Monday signed an MOU in the energy sector. As tensions escalate following the tanker attacks in the Gulf of Oman last week, a senior Iranian official said that Tehran has recently exposed "a large US cyber espionage network". The official also said that Iran is in charge of Gulf security and called on US forces to leave the region. Other reports that the OPEC member has been exceeding the inventory limit on low enriched uranium will also be sure to aggravate the situation in the region. Iran also said that the production of low-enriched uranium will quadruple, meanwhile reports stated that the 60-day deadline for Europe to save the Iranian deal will not be extended.

* ECB: Ahead of the Sintra meeting, ECB’s Coeure said the ECB should be conscious of the mixed messages data are sending, and that while the ECB should not blindly follow market pricing, it cannot ignore it; Coeure also insisted the central bank has ample policy tools, if required. Vice President de Guindos said that if inflation expectations became de-anchored, the ECB would act, however this was not the case at present.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.58 LOWER AT 51.93/BBL; BRENT (Q9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.07 LOWER AT USD 60.94/BBL: Crude prices are slightly on the backfoot to start the week, with geopolitical tensions failing to provide support, and option expiry on July WTI contributing towards Monday’s action. Analysts are continuing to highlight the oil market’s demand concerns as the overriding force currently. Citigroup energy analysts add said, “We’d bear in mind, however, that the demand fears are more of a look in the rear view mirror than a look ahead, driven or at least reinforced by revised 1Q data that was softer than expected… If nothing else, demand is likely to be seasonally stronger over the next few months.” Alternatively, BAML lowered its H2 forecast for oil, WTI to USD 56/bbl and Brent to USD 63/bbl, citing concern that while a Fed put, Saudi put and Trump put have been supportive of prices, if China were to continue importing Iranian crude WTI could drop to USD 40/bbl. Meanwhile, a date for the OPEC+ meeting has still not been decided; the proposed 3/4th July dates are seemingly a nonstarter after Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh announced he would not be able to attend, but instead suggested July 10/12th July.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 1 TICK HIGHER AT 126-31: Monday’s uneventful session was evident in the Tplex too, which saw US 10 years move sideways. Early on USTs moved in sympathy with the Bund, which saw fresh record low yields, before catching some mild bidding on the back of the disappointing US NY Fed manufacturing data. At settlement yields were mainly unchanged aside from the front-end, where the 2-year yield rose by c. 1.5bps, which saw the 2s/10s flatten by c. 2bps.

* S&P 500 0.1% at 2890, NASDAQ-100 0.6% at 7527, Dow Jones 0.1% at 26113, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.1%, Consumer Staples -0.2%, Energy 0.9%, Financials -0.9%, Health Care 0.5%, Industrials -0.3%, Information Technology 0.2%, Materials -0.9%, Telecommunication Services 1.1%, Utilities -0.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) moved higher as the Paris air show kicked off and the aircraft maker secured a number of orders. Facebook (FB) moved higher after SunTrust was optimistic that the social media platforms new cryptocurrency could "dramatically" expand the co.’s total addressable market and growth prospects. Disney (DIS) was moved lower after being downgraded by Imperial. Apple (AAPL) edged higher as Credit Suisse noted “less bad” than expected China shipment data, although gains were capped as JPM cut their PT for the iPhone maker. Dish (DISH) was buoyant on reports that it was leading the race to buy divestures from the T-Mobile US/Sprint merger. On which note, Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) both opened higher, after reports late last Friday suggest the DoJ were close to approving the merger. Incyte (INCY) moved higher after the drugmaker’s Ruxolitinib cream met primary end points in a phase 2 study. Mosaic (MOS) caught a bid after being upgraded at BAML. Symantec (SYMC) was buoyant after the co. received an upgrade at Mizuho. Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) jumped higher at the open after being upgraded by BMO Capital. Deere (DE) moved higher after the co. was upgraded at Baird. Kinder Morgan (KMI) were under pressure after being downgraded at Stifel. LyondellBasell (LYB) opened lower after being downgraded at Deutsche Bank. Conversely Corteva (CTVA) was upgraded at Deutsche Bank, and duly caught a tail wind. Array BioPharma (ARRY) shot higher on the news that Pfizer (PFE) would purchase the firm at a large premium. The latter fell slightly. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher after CEO Musk deleted his Twitter account, only months after reaching a settlement with the SEC regarding his Twitter use. General Electric (GE) was under pressure on dual negative stories; 1) they announced plans to cut roughly 450 jobs at two Swiss sites as it looks to address "challenges on the global energy markets” and 2) GE Aviation found unexpected wear in a part of its new engine for Boeing’s new 777X passenger plane, resulting in several months of delays while the component is redesigned and tested. A flattening treasury curve did little to help financial names, such as Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C), who moved lower throughout the session.

* FX WRAP: USD remained subdued ahead of key risk events later in the week, seeing downside in the wake of disappointing NY Fed Manufacturing survey data. Aside from the record monthly decline and negative print, June survey components were universally bleak, ‘cementing’ the consensus view that the Fed will flag an ease at the next meeting after this week’s convene. Likewise, EUR was uninspired, albeit seeing early strength on favourable rate differentials vs the buck, while the single currency may also have breathed a sigh of relief after an uptick in Eurozone Q1 wage and labour costs. JPY was flat, continuing to consolidate around 108.50 within a thin range. GBP traded with a downside bias, amid a lack of fundamental drivers, although one poll of conservative voters did show Conservative leadership candidate Boris Johnson with support in excess of 77%. CAD has marginally extended to the upside and is testing 1.3400 with no real reaction to Canadian securities data. NZD saw some strength on after a series of strong data prints (New Zealand Performance of Services Index, New Zealand ANZ Inflation Gauge) overnight. MXN lagged, with further negative comments from Moody’s following the country’s recent downgrade doing little to help. TRY found some respite after a welcome drop in Turkey’s jobless rate and continues to reverse post-Moody’s downgrade losses following the CBRT’s decision to link cheaper funding for primary banks to sovereign bond purchases, with the liquidity provision offered at 23% vs the current 24% benchmark rate. BRL took advantage of the Dollar’s minor downturn and got some independent impetus via latest reports on Brazil’s pension reform bill that the House Speaker hopes to see approved on June 26th. CNY was slightly firmer, with some traders pointing to the slightly firmer than expected overnight Yuan fix.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: dire state of NY manufacturing sector undermines the Greenback
content:
DXY

Having respected key technical resistance just above the 97.604 intraday high, the index drifted back down through 97.500 and then breached support in the 97.457-6 area (21 and 55 DMAs) before slipping to new Monday lows (97.329) on the back of a much bigger than expected fall in the Empire State index. Moreover, aside from the record monthly decline and negative print, June survey components were universally bleak, ‘cementing’ the consensus view that the Fed will flag an ease at the next meeting after this week’s convene. Back to the DXY, the next downside chart level ahead of 97.000 comes in at 97.067 and represents the 100 DMA, which could be vulnerable given a weaker than forecast NAHB survey.

EUR

The single currency has reaped the most reward from the Dollar’s demise, as Eur/Usd soaked up offers stacked between 1.1230-40 and rebounded further from 1.1205 lows to just shy of 1.1250 where stops are said to be sitting. The Euro may have also breathed a sigh of relief after an uptick in Eurozone Q1 wage and labour costs as a counter to the latest decline in 5 year-5 year inflation expectations to a fresh record low.

NZD/CAD/CHF

The Kiwi remains relatively firm vs its US counterpart following the overnight release of ANZ’s May inflation gauge showing firmer m/m and y/y prices, with Nzd/Usd pivoting 0.6500 and attention now switching to Westpac Q2 consumer sentiment later. The Loonie has marginally extended to the upside and is testing 1.3400 with no real reaction to Canadian securities data given impending comments from BoC’s Schembri, while the Franc has kept its head above parity, but softened against the aforementioned ‘outperforming’ Euro between 1.1221-1.1191 parameters following last Thursday’s dovish SNB hold with an operation tweak to the benchmark policy rate.

JPY/AUD/GBP

All marginally softer vs the Usd, but still rangy as the Yen holds within a 108.72-43 band awaiting the FOMC and then the BoJ that is also widely tipped to be dovish and reiterate a readiness to bump up stimulus if needed. Elsewhere, RBA minutes loom for the Aussie and further rate cuts are becoming more widespread amongst forecasters as Macquarie joins the band looking for an easing cycle with a 0.5% OCR prediction for the end of 2019. Sterling has not really benefited from some recent hawkish MPC commentary ahead of the BoE policy meet as the UK political void continues to weigh and Cable teetered above major chart and long term support at 1.2560, while Eur/Gbp posted fresh multi-month peaks at 0.8940.

EM

At last some respite for the Lira, albeit with help from retreating Buck noted above. However, Usd/Try started to pull back from 5.9250+ highs after a welcome drop in Turkey’s jobless rate and continues to reverse post-Moody’s downgrade gains following the CBRT’s decision to link cheaper funding for primary banks to sovereign bond purchases, with the liquidity provision offered at 23% vs the current 24% benchmark rate. Similarly, the Real took advantage of the Dollar’s downturn and got some independent impetus via latest reports on Brazil’s pension reform bill that the House Speaker hopes to see approved on June 26th. Usd/Brl now eyeing 3.8800 vs vs 3.9050+ at one stage and Usd/Try hovering just off sub-5.8550 lows.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 17th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

  • Apple Inc (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has had its price target cut at JP Morgan to USD 233 from USD 235, trimming its iPhone shipment forecasts due to the current US-China trade stand-off.
  • Boeing’s (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) CEO said that he could give a specific timetable for the return of the 737 MAX. However, the WSJ reported that the FAA could start flight trials of Boeing's proposed 737 MAX safety enhancement as early as this week. Sticking with the 737 MAX theme, Boeing CEO Muilenburg acknowledged that the aircraft maker made a "mistake" in its handling the issue of the cockpit warning light in its 737 Max aircraft, the NYT reported. Separately, Boeing engineers have been reducing the scope and duration of expensive physical tests used to certify its new 777X aircraft. However, cost-saving strategy may be at risk as due to increased scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers since the two fatal 737 MAX crashes.
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) will combine four separate units that invest in private companies, real estate and other hard-to-access deals and is reportedly planning a round of fundraising, according to the WSJ. Reportedly the division is likely to have USD 140bln in assets.
  • Intel (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has announced a program which aims support early-stage startup companies in Israel that target “industry inflection points” such as AI and other data-centric technologies.
  • Pfizer (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) will acquire Array BioPharma for USD 48.00 per share in cash, or for a total of USD 11.4bln. The Boards of Directors of both companies have approved the merger.
  • United Technologies (UTX) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) and Raytheon (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) have come under pressure since announcing their plans to merge, Barron’s note, making both “look appealing”. Barron’s suggest that, if the deal were to die, both stock prices could rally in relief. On the other hand, a “knottier” scenario would await if the merger went ahead. Elsewhere, newswires reported that Lockheed Martin (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) does not see an impact on its F-35 programme from the Raytheon-UTC merger.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) has started to offer a new grocery delivery subscription service called "Delivery Unlimited”, TechCrunch reports, which will put it in direct competition with Target's (TGT) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) Shipt and Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) Prime Now/Whole Foods services. Elsewhere, Mexico has blocked the supermarket co.’s proposed acquisition of grocery delivery app Cornershop for USD 225mln, owing to the co.’s size and Cornershop’s access to Walmart competitor data. Separately, Morgan Stanley raised its target price for the co. to USD 115 from USD 113, saying that the co. is driving profitable growth across its global portfolio.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has been accused by Genius Media Group of lifting and republishing its content found on Genius.com, resulting in a drop-in traffic for the site, the WSJ reports.
  • Amazon (AMZN) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is struggling to advance in the video game industry, having laid off dozens of employees last week in its video game development unit, according to the WSJ.
  • Incyte Corp (INCY) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced results from its Phase 2 study evaluating ruxolitinib cream, which is a nonsteroidal, anti-inflammatory, JAK inhibitor therapy. The study met its primary endpoint, where significantly more patients achieved a greater than or equal to 50% improvement from baseline compared to patients treated with a vehicle control.
  • JD.com (JD) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) could list its logistics unit in the future but it currently has no plans, newswires reported.
  • T-Mobile US (TMUS) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite), Sprint (S) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite), Dish Network (DISH) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite), Apollo Global Management (APO) – Dish Network is leading the race to buy assets that the DoJ is forcing Sprint and T-Mobile US to sell in order to get approval for their proposed merger, the WSJ reported, and is reportedly currently in talks to buy prepaid subscribers and wireless spectrum licenses. Private equity group Apollo Global is reportedly Dish to finance the bids. Elsewhere, in late Friday trade, reports suggested that the merger may be nearing DoJ approval.

S&P 500

  • American Airlines (AAL) (Industrials/Airlines) is urging a federal judge to end a work slowdown, allegedly caused by mechanics represented by the TWU-IAM Association, which it says has become devastating to the airline’s operations, newswires reported over the weekend.
  • FedEx Corp (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) - China's investigation into FedEx over misdirected mail should not be regarded as retaliation against the US, Chinese state news publication Xinhua said over the weekend.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) announced plans to cut roughly 450 jobs at two Swiss sites as it looks to address "challenges on the global energy markets”. Elsewhere, GE Aviation found unexpected wear in a part of its new engine for Boeing’s new 777X passenger plane, resulting in several months of delays while the component is redesigned and tested.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) CEO Barra said the company will not deploy a self-driving taxi fleet until after the technology is safer than a human driver.
  • Target (TGT) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) announced its payment registers was back online after an outage which prevented US customers from completing in-store purchases for about 2 hours over the weekend. It said the outage was not a data breach or security-related issue.
  • United Airlines (UAL) (Industrials/Airlines) - Tires on a United Airlines jet blew out during landing at Newark airport on Saturday, causing flight delays but no injuries to the 166 passengers on board, newswires reported. Elsewhere, United Airlines and Embraer (ERJ) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) sign a contract for up to 39 E175 jets, of a value of up to USD 1.9bln.

OTHER

  • Alibaba (BABA) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is proposing a one-to-eight stock split ahead of its Hong Kong listing later this year, which is expected to raise roughly USD 20bln, with the split to be presented to Shareholders for a vote at the AGM in Hong Kong on 15 July. 
  • Crane (CR) (Industrials/Machinery) has commenced a cash tender offer to acquire all of the outstanding shares of CIRCOR International (CIR) (Industrials/Machinery) for USD 45 per share, which is a 47% premium over the 20 May close, before the offer was initially made.
  • Deutsche Bank (DB, DBK GY) (Financials/Capital Markets) is mulling creating a “bad bank” to hold EUR 50bln of assets whilst shrinking or shutting its US equity trading business, according to the FT citing sources.
  • Keane Group (FRAC) (Energy/Energy Equipment & Services) will buy rival C&J Energy (CJ) (Energy/Energy Equipment & Services) for USD 745.7mln in an all-stock deal. The companies said in a statement that the deal is expected to add to cash flow immediately and they expect annual cost savings of USD 100 million within the first 12 months after closing.
  • Lufthansa (LHA GY) (Industrials/Airlines) cut FY19 revenue guidance to low single digit growth from mid-single digit growth previously, dragging European airline names lower.
  • Prosperity Bancshares (PB) (Financials/Banks) said it has agreed to buy Texas-based LegacyTexas Financial Group (LTXB) (Financials/Banks) for USD 2.1 billion, or USD 41.78 per share.
  • UBS (UBS, UBSG SW) (Financials/Capital Markets) - CRCC confirmed it will exclude the Co. from bond deal due to recent offensive comments.
  • UniQure (QURE) (Health Care/Biotechnology) is exploring options with advisers, which reportedly include a potential sale, amid interest from other pharma and biotech companies looking to expand in gene therapy. Analysts at Cantor Fitzgerald said the co. may attract interest from companies such as Pfizer (PFE) and Europe’s Sanofi (SNY, SAN FP).

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 17th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European stocks are flat/mixed in a continuation of the cautious tone seen in Asia
  • Most major FX pairs remain rangebound ahead of an action-packed week
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US NY Fed Manufacturing and ECB’s Draghi

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began mixed with the region cautious ahead of the upcoming slate of central bank activity and after last Friday’s losses on Wall St, where the tech sector underperformed as chipmakers suffered from losses in Broadcom. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (Unch) were varied with Australia subdued by losses in telecoms, while Tokyo trade was underpinned as exporters benefitted from a weaker JPY. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were both positive for most of early trade after the PBoC conducted a substantial liquidity injection and as the 2nd phase of its RRR cut took effect today which releases CNY 100bln of funds. However, momentum in the mainland eventually waned while Hong Kong outperformed after Chief Executive Lam postponed the extradition bill indefinitely. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the gains in Japanese stocks and following the bear flattening seen in US on Friday, with demand also dampened by the absence of BoJ Rinban operations in the market today.

PBoC injected CNY 150bln via 14-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY 120bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8940 (Prev. 6.8937)

Chinese Securities Regulator is reportedly urging inter-bank liquidity support measures for smaller non-financial institutions, according to sources. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam suspended the extradition bill indefinitely and stated that the bill has caused plenty of division, while around 2mln protesters were said to have demonstrated over the weekend calling for the complete withdrawal of the extradition bill and for Lam to resign. (Newswires)

US

Mexican Economy Minister Graciela Marquez Colin said on Friday that a retaliation list is ready if the US raises tariffs. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson’s plans to withhold Brexit bill payments could be thwarted by Attorney General Cox’s legal advice as he warned that linking Brexit bill payments to progress in trade talks would be illegal. In other news, UK Health Minister Hancock said he will be backing Boris Johnson in the leadership race. (Telegraph/FT)

ECB’s Nowotny (Hawkish) said ECB still has tools to support Eurozone economy in the event of a recession or deflation risk and suggested that additional instruments are not needed in the foreseeable future. (Newswires)

ECB’s De Guindos (Neutral) suggested that the ECB will take action in the event that inflation expectations are de-anchored. (Newswires)

ECB's Coeure (Neutral) said the question is which instrument or combination of instruments would be best suited to the circumstances, and added that the ECB would have to consider whether a tiering system. (Newswires)

Bundesbank Monthly Report says German economy is to contract slightly in Q2, economic outlook will fall slightly in Q2 as one-off effects that supported Q1 expansion fades. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed France at 'AA'; Outlook Stable and Moody’s downgraded Turkey by one notch to B1 from Ba3; Outlook remains Negative. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European stocks are mixed in a continuation of the cautious tone seen in Asia, ahead of the central bank-packed week. Sectors are mixed with underperformance in the energy sector amid price action in the complex, whilst financial names lead the gains as banks benefit from the higher yields. In terms of movers, airline stocks took a hit after Lufthansa (-11.3%) cut its revenue and adj. EBIT margin guidance, citing increased competition in the market, and as such, Ryanair (-5.9%), easyJet (-5.3%) and Air France (-3.6%) all slipped in tandem. Elsewhere, Airbus (+1.0%) shares are buoyed as the Paris Air Show gets underway with reports noting the Co. has won a major 100-plane order over Boeing. Finally, Deutsche Bank (+2.2%) shares are feeling some reprieve after sources stated that the bank is mulling holding EUR 50bln of assets in a “bad bank” whilst also shrinking or shutting its US equity trading business. 

FX

USD - The Dollar has maintained its post-US data positivity and the DXY is pivoting 97.500 with resistance close by in the form of a 61.8% Fib retracement of the relatively pronounced pull-back from May 23 ytd highs of 97.373 to June 7 lows at 96.451, and support sitting around 97.457-6 where 21 and 55 DMAs converge. In terms of fundamentals, the looming FOMC will be paramount as markets widely if not unanimously anticipate another dovish shift from the Fed and signal that rates will be cut in July. However, ongoing global trade wars and geopolitical developments are propping up the Greenback and other safe-havens to varying degrees.

NZD/AUD - Bucking the broad consolidative G10 trend and largely rangebound Usd/major trade, the Kiwi has bounced back to straddle 0.6500 and appears to be deriving some impetus from firmer NZ inflation metrics ahead of Westpac’s Q2 consumer survey tonight. Moreover, Aud/Nzd cross-flows may be supportive as the Aussie remains depressed around 1.0550 and 0.6875 vs its US counterpart amidst more dovish RBA calls (Macquarie now expecting the OCR to decline to 0.5% by year end) in advance of June policy meeting minutes in the early hours on Tuesday.

EUR/CAD/JPY/GBP/CHF - As noted above, narrow parameters vs the Buck for the most part as the single currency holds within a 1.1205-25 band and just above decent option expiry interest at the 1.1200 strike (1 bn). Contacts also believe that reserve managers are lurking at the big figure on the buy-side, while nearest chart levels are seen at 1.1171 (76.4% Fib of the move from 1.1116 to 1.1348) and 1.1250 (latter more psychological than technical). Meanwhile, aside from the aforementioned Fed meet, the Euro may get some independent direction from the ECB’s annual Sintra conference that kicks off today with an opening speech from President Draghi. Elsewhere, the Loonie is also sitting tight between 1.3405-20 and awaiting a speech from BoC’s Schembri, but Deutsche Bank expects the headline pair to spike on FOMC disappointment given overly dovish expectations and some BoC catch up, targeting 1.3665 with a 1.3225 stop (recent low). The Yen is holding in a 108.43-70 range ahead of the BoJ on Friday and Cable is hovering just below 1.2600 pre-BoE, UK CPI and retail sales with Pound bears aware that 1.2560 is last month’s trend low. Finally, the Franc is holding just above parity post-last Thursday’s SNB and Eur/Chf remains confined either side of 1.1200.

EM - The Lira has pared some losses from 5.9250+ lows vs the Dollar after Moody’s downgraded Turkey’s credit rating deeper into junk with the aid of a much needed improvement in unemployment, while the CBRT has enhanced liquidity provisions for primary banks via a facility discounted by 1% vs the 24% benchmark rate and based on government bond holdings.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures continue to decline ahead of a risk-packed week with a number of bearish factors looming over the complex. 1) US crude stocks have been on the rise, with inventory reports via both API and EIA printing surprise builds for two straight weeks. Traders will now be wondering whether these increases will be enough for OPEC+ to possibly revise its output cut pact, with the meeting now seemingly taking place in the first week of July according to the Saudi Energy Minister. 2) Last week saw all three monthly oil reports (EIA, OPEC, IEA) cut their respective global oil growth demand forecasts amid rising threats of trade wars, whilst hopes for a deal between China and the US at the G20 summit seem slim. 3) Last week, speculators trimmed net long positions in Brent longs (-12.3k lots), but WTI saw a more significant reduction (-53.96k lots) as speculators try to balance rising US inventories with Middle-East tensions and potential OPEC+ reaction. WTI futures are hovering just above the USD 52/bbl mark (low USD 52.07/bbl) whiles Brent futures lost the USD 62/bbl handle, albeit remain off lows (USD 61.56/bbl). Elsewhere, precious metals are subdued, potentially on some profit taking ahead of this week’s key risk events including BoJ, BoE and Fed and a slew of ECB speakers. Gold has lost further ground below the USD 1350/oz level after a failed attempt at breaching long-term resistance at USD 1358.50/bbl last week. Meanwhile, copper is little changed amid the indecisive risk tone ahead of the aforementioned risk events.

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih stated that the OPEC meeting will likely be in the first week of July and noted that OPEC are moving towards a consensus to on the extension of the output cut. The Energy Minister also expects global oil demand to exceed 100mln BPD in 2019 and says oil demand growth is holding up despite trade disputes. (Newswires)

China (May) Iron ore output +1.5% Y/Y to 70.8mln Tonnes, Refined Copper output -5.2% Y/Y to 711k Tonnes. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is considering a full range of options regarding increasing tensions with Iran, including military options but added that President Trump does not want to go to war. (CNN)

Iran are reportedly exceeding the inventory limit on low enriched uranium, according to sources. Furthermore, Iran said the production of low-enriched uranium will quadruple (no time frame), meanwhile reports stated that the 60-day deadline for Europe to save the Iranian deal will not be extended. (Newswires)

FX

USD - The Dollar has maintained its post-US data positivity and the DXY is pivoting 97.500 with resistance close by in the form of a 61.8% Fib retracement of the relatively pronounced pull-back from May 23 ytd highs of 97.373 to June 7 lows at 96.451, and support sitting around 97.457-6 where 21 and 55 DMAs converge. In terms of fundamentals, the looming FOMC will be paramount as markets widely if not unanimously anticipate another dovish shift from the Fed and signal that rates will be cut in July. However, ongoing global trade wars and geopolitical developments are propping up the Greenback and other safe-havens to varying degrees.

NZD/AUD - Bucking the broad consolidative G10 trend and largely rangebound Usd/major trade, the Kiwi has bounced back to straddle 0.6500 and appears to be deriving some impetus from firmer NZ inflation metrics ahead of Westpac’s Q2 consumer survey tonight. Moreover, Aud/Nzd cross-flows may be supportive as the Aussie remains depressed around 1.0550 and 0.6875 vs its US counterpart amidst more dovish RBA calls (Macquarie now expecting the OCR to decline to 0.5% by year end) in advance of June policy meeting minutes in the early hours on Tuesday.

EUR/CAD/JPY/GBP/CHF - As noted above, narrow parameters vs the Buck for the most part as the single currency holds within a 1.1205-25 band and just above decent option expiry interest at the 1.1200 strike (1 bn). Contacts also believe that reserve managers are lurking at the big figure on the buy-side, while nearest chart levels are seen at 1.1171 (76.4% Fib of the move from 1.1116 to 1.1348) and 1.1250 (latter more psychological than technical). Meanwhile, aside from the aforementioned Fed meet, the Euro may get some independent direction from the ECB’s annual Sintra conference that kicks off today with an opening speech from President Draghi. Elsewhere, the Loonie is also sitting tight between 1.3405-20 and awaiting a speech from BoC’s Schembri, but Deutsche Bank expects the headline pair to spike on FOMC disappointment given overly dovish expectations and some BoC catch up, targeting 1.3665 with a 1.3225 stop (recent low). The Yen is holding in a 108.43-70 range ahead of the BoJ on Friday and Cable is hovering just below 1.2600 pre-BoE, UK CPI and retail sales with Pound bears aware that 1.2560 is last month’s trend low. Finally, the Franc is holding just above parity post-last Thursday’s SNB and Eur/Chf remains confined either side of 1.1200.

EM - The Lira has pared some losses from 5.9250+ lows vs the Dollar after Moody’s downgraded Turkey’s credit rating deeper into junk with the aid of a much needed improvement in unemployment, while the CBRT has enhanced liquidity provisions for primary banks via a facility discounted by 1% vs the 24% benchmark rate and based on government bond holdings.

FIXED INCOME

A relatively mundane Monday thus far, and not many if any catalysts for core debt, but having staged a recovery rally in early trade bonds have faded on what looks like a lack of follow-through buying as much as anything else. Firmer Eurozone pay and employment costs may have prompted some selling as an offset to sliding inflation expectations given that the 5 year-5 year forward continues to set record lows on a daily basis, but Bunds are holding just above Eurex session lows as Italian BTPs and other peripheral paper retreat/unwind earlier outperformance. Conversely, Gilts have retreated to a fresh Liffe base at 130.04 (-21 ticks vs +7 ticks at best) and US Treasuries are probing new overnight session troughs with the curve steeper ahead of the Fed and a couple of releases today (NY manufacturing survey and NAHB).

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures continue to decline ahead of a risk-packed week with a number of bearish factors looming over the complex. 1) US crude stocks have been on the rise, with inventory reports via both API and EIA printing surprise builds for two straight weeks. Traders will now be wondering whether these increases will be enough for OPEC+ to possibly revise its output cut pact, with the meeting now seemingly taking place in the first week of July according to the Saudi Energy Minister. 2) Last week saw all three monthly oil reports (EIA, OPEC, IEA) cut their respective global oil growth demand forecasts amid rising threats of trade wars, whilst hopes for a deal between China and the US at the G20 summit seem slim. 3) Last week, speculators trimmed net long positions in Brent longs (-12.3k lots), but WTI saw a more significant reduction (-53.96k lots) as speculators try to balance rising US inventories with Middle-East tensions and potential OPEC+ reaction. WTI futures are hovering just above the USD 52/bbl mark (low USD 52.07/bbl) whiles Brent futures lost the USD 62/bbl handle, albeit remain off lows (USD 61.56/bbl). Elsewhere, precious metals are subdued, potentially on some profit taking ahead of this week’s key risk events including BoJ, BoE and Fed and a slew of ECB speakers. Gold has lost further ground below the USD 1350/oz level after a failed attempt at breaching long-term resistance at USD 1358.50/bbl last week. Meanwhile, copper is little changed amid the indecisive risk tone ahead of the aforementioned risk events.

Looking ahead, CPI and retail sales are the last major data inputs for the BoE to ponder this week, while the Tory leadership race gets down to business this week as only 2 candidates will emerge and go head to head. 17th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began mixed with the region cautious ahead of the upcoming slate of central bank activity and after last Friday’s losses on Wall St, where the tech sector underperformed as chipmakers suffered from Broadcom’s downbeat view for the industry due to the Huawei ban. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were varied with Australia subdued by losses in telecoms as Vocus Group shares fell around 30% after AGL Energy dropped its pursuit of the Co. for a 2nd time, while Tokyo trade was underpinned as exporters benefitted from a weaker JPY but with Japan Display among the exceptions after TPK Holding withdrew from its planned investment in the Co. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were both positive for most of early trade after the PBoC conducted a substantial liquidity injection and as the 2nd phase of its RRR cut took effect today which releases CNY 100bln of funds. However, momentum in the mainland eventually waned while Hong Kong outperformed after Chief Executive Lam postponed the extradition bill indefinitely.

UK aviation names – Industry leaders have warned that a no-deal Brexit is “a critical risk” to UK aviation, and added that businesses will continue to prepare for the October 31st Brexit deadline. (Times)

UK stocks – UK Treasury stated that UK-listed firms will be able to list in mainland China via a new stock link. Firms will be able to sell shares through dual listings on the Shanghai and London Stock Exchanges. (BBC)

UK betting names – Co. costs are rising and demand from customers are falling due to the new regulations around FOBTs, industry agreements to curb advertising during sports games and tougher anti-money laundering riles. (FT)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 17th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets began mixed with the region cautious ahead of the upcoming slate of key risk events
  • Price action in FX was relatively quiet amid a lack of tier 1 data releases, DXY slightly pulled back from Friday’s data-driven gains
  • Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson’s plans to withhold Brexit bill payments could be thwarted by Attorney General Cox’s legal advice
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, ECB’s de Cos and Draghi

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began mixed with the region cautious ahead of the upcoming slate of central bank activity and after last Friday’s losses on Wall St, where the tech sector underperformed as chipmakers suffered from losses in Broadcom. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) were varied with Australia subdued by losses in telecoms, while Tokyo trade was underpinned as exporters benefitted from a weaker JPY. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were both positive for most of early trade after the PBoC conducted a substantial liquidity injection and as the 2nd phase of its RRR cut took effect today which releases CNY 100bln of funds. However, momentum in the mainland eventually waned while Hong Kong outperformed after Chief Executive Lam postponed the extradition bill indefinitely. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the gains in Japanese stocks and following the bear flattening seen in US on Friday, with demand also dampened by the absence of BoJ Rinban operations in the market today.

PBoC injected CNY 150bln via 14-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY 120bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8940 (Prev. 6.8937)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam suspended the extradition bill indefinitely and stated that the bill has caused plenty of division, while around 2mln protesters were said to have demonstrated over the weekend calling for the complete withdrawal of the extradition bill and for Lam to resign. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson’s plans to withhold Brexit bill payments could be thwarted by Attorney General Cox’s legal advice as he warned that linking Brexit bill payments to progress in trade talks would be illegal. In other news, UK Health Minister Hancock said he will be backing Boris Johnson in the leadership race. (Telegraph/FT)

Conservative Party donors have opened secret discussions with Nigel Farage about an electoral pact which would see the party not stand candidates against the Brexit Party in dozens of seats at a snap general election. (Telegraph)

Following the Conservative Party leadership debate, Sky News concluded that overall “there was probably no clear winner. Mr Johnson's supporters will no doubt claim it was him since he didn't get dragged into an unseemly row about Brexit or his character”. (Sky News)

British Chambers of Commerce said its survey showed UK firms look set to reduce 2019 investment by the most in a decade as Brexit drags on. (Newswires)

ECB’s Nowotny said ECB still has tools to support Eurozone economy in the event of a recession or deflation risk and suggested that additional instruments are not needed in the foreseeable future. (Newswires)

ECB’s De Guindos suggested that the ECB will take action in the event that inflation expectations are de-anchored. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed France at 'AA'; Outlook Stable and Moody’s downgraded Turkey by one notch to B1 from Ba3; Outlook remains Negative. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jun) M/M 0.3% (Prev. 0.9%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (Jun) Y/Y 0.0% (Prev. 0.1%)

FX

Price action was relatively quiet amid a lack of tier 1 data releases and ahead of the central bank meetings from the BoJ, BoE and FOMC, in which the DXY slightly pulled back from Friday’s data-driven gains. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts found some mild reprieve from the recent selling pressure as EUR/USD rebounded from support around the 1.1200 level and the nearby 61.8% Fibonacci retracement of the late-May to early-June rally, while GBP/USD was also off worse levels but has so far failed to reclaim the 1.2600 handle. USD/JPY remained supported by the positive risk appetite in Japan and antipodeans nursed recent losses after NZD support near 8-month lows, while AUD/USD composed itself despite further dovish forecasts for rates with Macquarie now expecting the RBA to lower the Cash Rate to 0.5% by year-end.

 

An ally of Turkish President Erdogan has suggested that the nation needs to work on a ‘new and fair’ approach to controlling the FX rate that better suits the domestic economy and citizens. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were uneventful and reflected the indecisive risk tone overnight with WTI crude futures little changed throughout the session to hold on to Friday’s gains, as ongoing geopolitical tensions related to Iran provide a floor for prices and with a decline in the latest Baker Hughes rig count adding to the factors keeping crude afloat. Elsewhere, gold was steady ahead of this week’s FOMC meeting where participants eye whether the Fed will pave the way for a cut next month and with prices also contained after recent USD strength spurred a pullback in the precious metal, while copper attempted to recoup some on the recent losses but with the rebound limited by the overall cautious sentiment.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (14/June): oil rigs -1 at 788; nat gas -5 rigs at 181; total rigs -6 at 969. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih stated that the OPEC meeting will likely be in the first week of July and hopes for the group to reach consensus to extend the oil output pact. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is considering a full range of options regarding increasing tensions with Iran, including military options but added that President Trump does not want to go to war. (CNN)

Iranian fast boats were reportedly preventing tugboats from toeing the Norwegian damaged vessel according to a US official, while there were also reports the UK is almost certain that a branch of the Iranian military launched the tanker attack in the Gulf of Oman. (Newswires)

Arab League called for restraint in the Gulf and noted there are risks of a deepening confrontation, while it sees behaviour of a "certain party" as worsening the situation. (Newswires)

US

A solid batch of data out of the US saw the curve bear-flatten, with shorter-dated yields rising about 2bps (at settle) vs yields on 30s declining by around 1bps. Early trade was defined by risk-off type flows, which led to some concerns that the 10-year yield could breach the 2.00% mark. However, haven trade was usurped by decent fundamentals, with traders reducing bets that the Fed could cut rates next week in wake of the upbeat data. The implied probability of a June rate cut has fallen to around 25% from around 33% on Thursday, while July pricing eased slightly too. However, the TPLEX found buyers after the inflation gauges in the Michigan Sentiment data declined sharply, challenging Fed Chair Powell's view that inflation weakness was transitory, and perhaps giving further credence to the notion that the Fed has grounds to cut based on inflation alone, let alone for "insurance" reasons to guard against the fall-out from global trade tensions. At settlement, major curve spreads were narrower to the tune of 2bps. US T-Note futures (M9) settled 2 ticks lower at 126-30.

Mexican Economy Minister Graciela Marquez Colin said on Friday that a retaliation list is ready if the US raises tariffs. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia starts the week cautious ahead of central bank announcements and after last Friday's tech declines on Wall St
content:
Asia equity markets begin mixed with the region cautious ahead of the upcoming slate of central bank activity and after last Friday’s losses on Wall St, where the tech sector underperformed as chipmakers suffered from Broadcom’s downbeat view for the industry due to the Huawei ban. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) are varied with Australia subdued by losses in telecoms as Vocus Group shares fell around 30% after AGL Energy dropped its pursuit of the Co. for a 2nd time, while Tokyo trade is underpinned as exporters benefit from a weaker JPY but with Japan Display among the exceptions after TPK Holding withdrew from its planned investment in the Co. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) are both higher after the PBoC conducted a substantial liquidity injection and as the 2nd phase of its RRR cut took effect today which releases CNY 100bln of funds, while outperformance is seen in Hong Kong after Chief Executive Lam postponed the extradition bill indefinitely although protestors continued to call for a complete withdrawal of the bill and her resignation.

In FX markets, price action is relatively quiet amid a lack of tier 1 data releases and ahead of the central bank meetings from the BoJ, BoE and FOMC, with the greenback only slightly pulling back from Friday’s data-driven gains. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts found some mild reprieve from the recent selling pressure with EUR/USD rebounding from support around the 1.1200 level and the nearby 61.8% Fibonacci retracement of the late-May to early-June rally, while GBP/USD is also off worse levels but has so far failed to reclaim the 1.2600 handle. Elsewhere, USD/JPY remains supported by the positive risk appetite in Japan and antipodeans nurse recent losses in which NZD rebounded from support near 8-month lows, while AUD/USD attempts to compose itself despite further dovish forecasts for rates with Macquarie now expecting the RBA to lower the Cash Rate to 0.5% by year-end.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower amid the gains in Japanese stocks and following the bear flattening seen in US on Friday, with demand also dampened by the absence of BoJ Rinban operations in the market today.
